Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an electron probe microanalyzer for Earth Science and Materials research and education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide funds to acquire a state-of-the-art electron probe microanalyzer (EPMA) to support numerous funded and ongoing research projects. As a cornerstone instrument within the Center for Materials Characterization, the EPMA is vital to the scientific health of the university and region by providing a versatile platform for the analysis of major, minor, and trace elements to promote NSF-funded research in the solid Earth Sciences and in Materials Science and Engineering. The EPMA will directly enhance undergraduate and graduate student research, teaching, and hands-on experiences through directed research and classroom projects. Adding this instrument will fill a critical need in the regional analytical infrastructure, promote cross-disciplinary research, and greatly enhance the quality and scope of Earth Science and Materials research and education in the Interior Northwest.

Major research objectives for the EPMA include the following: 1. Analysis of major, minor, and trace element compositions and zoning in metamorphic minerals to infer petrogenetic processes and pressure-temperature conditions and evolution; 2. Major, minor, and trace element analysis of igneous minerals to constrain (a) melt evolution at mid-ocean ridges, (b) formation of the mantle lithosphere, and (c) felsic magmagenesis and formation of continental crust (in conjunction with U-Pb geochronology); 3. Major and minor element analysis of functional ceramics, e.g. barium polytitanates and lanthanide perovskites, to evaluate how vacancy-producing chemical substitutions affect physical and electrical properties; 4. Composition maps of tooth enamel to understand mineralization processes of modern teeth (which has implications for interpreting chemical and isotopic data) and trace element uptake; 5. Trace element analysis of minerals for geologic thermometry as applied to understanding the conditions of formation of mylonites and dateable minerals like zircon and titanite; 6. Major and minor element analysis of magnetic shape memory alloys, e.g. Ni-Mn-Ga, to determine micrometer-scale element distributions and their influence on mechanical and magnetic properties; 7. Minor element contamination of materials of interest to the nuclear industry, especially graphite- molten salt interactions; and 8. Major and minor element stoichiometry of transition-metal dichalcogenides for electronics materials research and development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to purchase an electron probe microanalyzer (EPMA) for use in geological and (solid) materials research. We were successful in this endeavor in that we researched instrument capabilities to identify specific needs, solicited bids from competing companies, selected the best fit for our institutional needs, and oversaw instrument selection. We now have a fully functional EPMA available for use to a broad community of researchers and students interested in chemical analysis of solid materials.

More specifically, within the constraints of our budget, we wanted to maximize the analytical capabilities, e.g. major and trace elements, range of elements across the periodic table, X-ray mapping at high beam current, etc. In balancing cost against capabilities, we especially wanted to maximize the number of wavelength dispersive spectrometers and the capabilities of the diffracting crystals. We also wanted to ensure both the long-term reliability of the instrument, and assess each instrument's unique capabilities. Examples include maximum beam intensity and stability, column stability, spectrometer count rates and positioning reproducibility, electron detector resolution, light optics, stage reproducibility and stability, and long-term reliability. The instrument had to include include Probe for EPMA commercial software to ensure cross-institutional compatibility.

Ultimately, we completed purchase and installation of the EPMA in summer, 2016. This required first assessing instrument capabilities with on-site visits to Stanford (JEOL) and University of Wisconsin (Cameca), and compiling reliability/service statistics for over a dozen instruments by sending a questionnaire to over a dozen users. We also solicited bids, which required several iterations to ensure all our required criteria were met.

New assistant professor Dr. V. Dorsey Wanless participated in site visits and has been involved in all discussions and decision-making. This has helped train her in processes of instrument purchase. We have initiated broader training of faculty and staff, and is 2017 will move on to focused training of graduate students. Dr. Nick Bulloss manages the EPMA and has been trained both in the Cameca software and Probe for EPMA. We are planning a new graduate seminar for spring 2017 to provide students with practical training in EPMA capabilities, both to foster technical education and to help support MS and PhD projects, primarily in petrology, geochemistry and geochronology. The EPMA will also be used in undergraduate petrology classes starting in early 2017 to introduce students to methods of quantitative microanalysis.

The new instrumentation will promote research in the Earth Sciences for graduate students, faculty, and undergraduate students in petrology, geochemistry and geochronology. It will also promote research in Materials Science for graduate students, faculty, and undergraduate students in ceramics, thin film, and other solid materials research.

The new instrument provides cornerstone capabilities in electron beam analysis at Boise State for research activities in Earth Science and Materials Science. More generally, this project has welded the Department of Geosciences and the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Boise State through cooperative agreements regarding instrument purchase and use, and technician support.
